sentence: Consistent with hypotheses, higher emotional support during pregnancy showed a significant direct effect on perceived resilience to stress during pregnancy, even after covarying for instrumental support and other covariates (Figure 1a).

Significant indirect effects are bolded for emphasis.In contrast to the effects on perceived resilience, emotional support did not show a direct effect on physiological (HRV) recovery during pregnancy; instead, this association was moderated by life stress (Figure 1a).

After covarying for emotional support, instrumental support during pregnancy was not associated with perceived resilience or HRV recovery, nor did it interact with life stress to predict either variable (Figure 1b).

Similar to the findings in the externalizing behavior model, higher emotional support during pregnancy was significantly associated with perceived resilience to stress during pregnancy, which subsequently predicted lower offspring internalizing behaviors at age 2–3 years (Figure 2a).

Instrumental support did not have a direct effect on perceived resilience or HRV recovery, nor did it have a direct or indirect effect on offspring internalizing behaviors through the mediators (Figure 2b; Table 2).

Consistent with hypotheses, higher emotional support during pregnancy showed a significant direct effect on perceived resilience to stress during pregnancy, even after covarying for instrumental support and other covariates (Figure 1a).

Instrumental support did not have a direct effect on perceived resilience or HRV recovery, nor did it have a direct or indirect effect on offspring internalizing behaviors through the mediators (Figure 2b; Table 2).

Consistent with hypotheses, higher emotional support during pregnancy showed a significant direct effect on perceived resilience to stress during pregnancy, even after covarying for instrumental support and other covariates (Figure 1a).

In contrast to the effects on perceived resilience, emotional support did not show a direct effect on physiological (HRV) recovery during pregnancy; instead, this association was moderated by life stress (Figure 1a).
